EasyMock and JMock can be used to mock any interface (and classes). 
You ca=
n try to use it to mock jdbc object, but it might be heavy if
your design i=
s not prepared for it (You might have to write an
important number of mock =
expectations).

Alternatively, you could also have a look to DBUnit.  But f=
or that,
you need a DB.

I know it is not the answer that you expected, but=
 I hope it will help
you.

Gilles

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "dee101_19=
99" <delee@...> wrote:
>
> Hi,
> 
> I apologise for the repeat post, but th=
ought I might get some answers
> second time around :-) Thanks.
> 
> I want=
 to unit-test my database application, but am a bit confused
> after readin=
g Massol's 'JUnit in Action' and Rainsberger's 'JUnit
> Recipes'. Granted t=
hese books were published in 2004 and 2005
> respectively, so may be a bit =
outdated.
> 
> JUnit in Action uses DynaMock for its database testing examp=
les in
> Chapter 11. Does DynaMock still exist or is JMock the new version =
of
> it? But JMock doesn't contain any specific SQL classes, like
> MockCon=
nection, or?
> 
> EasyMock doesn't seem to have any SQL specific classes ei=
ther.
> 
> So what's the latest recommendation of a mock object implementat=
ion
> when testing database applications?
> 
> Thanks,
> Deirdre
